Its a function of too much supply relative to demand ( a function of 30+ years of demand side bias policies) - call it 'supply side saturation'.

Because of lack of demand, investors, who have more money than ever, can't get a good return on it. This is there livelihood. So, when some sector shows up with decent return they flood that sector - creating the bubble.

The other thing is they demand deregulation. Laws exist to channel greed into the development of socially constructive enterprises (orthodox investing). But when there isn't enough ROI from orthodox investing, unorthodox will have to do, and so the demand for deregulation becomes insistent. "Unfortunately, this involves isolating individual items from the whole climate complex."

Yes, Susan. This is precisely the point I've been making about Andy and others. There's endless parsing and a complete refusal to look at the overall picture. Such and such a study implies that the odds of this particular phenomenon occurring on a particular timeline laid out a decade ago might be somewhat off the mark — therefore there is a possibility that perhaps under certain circumstances global warming might not be coming at us as quickly and forcefully as some may think or at least portions of some of the earlier models might not be as robust as some believed.

Translation: It's a problem for the next generation; let's burn a little natural gas and teach the kids how to communicate.

Meanwhile, major climate events keep piling on top of one another so fast it makes your head spin. And some of those events are pretty darn robust. The arctic ice was supposed to be reduced to the level it hit last summer in 2075 to 2125, for heaven's sake. Millions upon millions of people have been forced from their homes or lost their livelihoods due to floods. 13,000 people die in a heat wave in France. The U.S. drought is affecting GLOBAL food prices. The list goes on…and on.

Do something? Well, let's don't be hasty. Some people would find a carbon tax inconvenient.

I've got an idea: Let's burn a little natural gas and teach the kids how to communicate.

The Fed, under Bernanke, is running negative interest rates again, and the result is a stock market bubble - even PK can not dismissive this. Hence he focuses on bonds in his colum, rather than stocks where the real problem lies..

My father was in the Civilian Conservation Corps, helping the nation with projects funded by the nation. His immigrant father was a tailor in Iowa City; needless to say, men stopped having suits made, and he actually sold pencils on city streets. The family struggled throughout the Depression. The CCC sent $25 a month to his family, which helped keep his brother in Medical School at UI. My father received $5.00 a month, and the Corps housed and fed them well.

In another era, families survived by the work of their hands: my grandmother's large vegetable garden fed them; my father labored with other young men in the CCC. My mother's family suffered, their only protein for one year the walnuts they gathered (she could barely look at a walnut thereafter). Her father, a housepainter, was soon unemployed, their income her mother's slim wages as a hotel maid. My mother had only two skirts and one blouse throughout high school.

Do we have the skills and coping abilities eighty years later to manage a prolonged financial depression in the same way?

We no longer seem to have the national will or political stability to establish sweeping programs like the CCC.

Traveling in almost any part of the country one must be impressed with the abundance of government projects that were completed by the WPA, PWA,CCC, TVA and other government agencies. Parks, playgrounds, dams, lakes, paved roads, electrical service as well as water and sewer systems are all part of this legacy. Clearly the 30's generation served the future well. Today's government- not so much.

When I was in second grade, our teacher took my class on a trip to the public library with the name Carnegie chiseled above the massive doorway. Inside I was in awe of the enormous amount of shelved books. Then, when I signed for MY VERY OWN library card that allowed me to borrow books of my own choosing, I thought I'd reached nirvana. You see, our parents were immigrants, working earnestly to put food on the table and pay the bills. At the time, there was no money for books. There was one book in our home.
As a first generation American I was curious about the ways of American families and how we could fit into this society. Along with my schooling, the library helped me do this. When I visited it every week, I went first to this set of orange clad biographies, written expressly for the young - to learn about American heroes. One of those books was chosen along with one from children's fiction. These gave me insight as to how some American families lived. Then there were the classics, some pure fantasy, that enriched my imagination. How fortunate I was to have access to this special place.
Now 60 years later, in retirement, I volunteer at our public library as a Friend, in appreciation for the building that has meant so much to me. Early on, I thought the library belonged to Mr. Carnegie. Fortunately it belongs to the community. His gift of libraries to this nation enriched many lives, and I for one, thank him.
